articles.title: MARCH 1988
articles.summary: This document outlines a detailed schedule of astronomical events and meetings from March through May 1988. Key activities include general meetings featuring guest speakers like Dr. Jack Marling on filters and Dr. Mabith Wald on the U.S. Space Program, alongside regular field expeditions for observation at Fremont Peak State Park and a Messier Marathon. The calendar also notes board meetings, an introductory astronomy class, planned public observing sessions for Astronomy Day, and the 8th Annual Astronomical Auction.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article announces the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) March 5th general meeting, featuring Dr. Jack Marling discussing the current state of astronomical filters for improved observation and astrophotography. It also addresses the overlooked board elections from February, stating that nominations and elections for the Board of Directors, including the need for new members, will take place at the March meeting.

articles.title: Nominations from the floor
articles.summary: This document outlines the procedures for nominating individuals or running for the SJAA Board. Prospective nominees require prior permission, and candidates can either contact the election committee directly or be nominated by a friend at the election. Eligibility criteria include one year of SJAA membership or attendance at six board meetings.

articles.title: Officers
articles.summary: At its first meeting following the election on March 26, the newly-constituted Board will elect four officers to serve a one-year term. These officers will be chosen from among the Board members themselves.

articles.title: Board Meetings
articles.summary: The article describes monthly, open board meetings where club activities like star parties, the annual auction, and picnics are planned, encouraging members to attend for involvement and potential board membership. It also announces the 8th annual Astronomical Auction to be held on May 7th in Los Gatos, featuring a flea market/swap meet, silent bids, and a main auction.

articles.title: Flea Market or Auction?
articles.summary: This article provides guidelines for participants deciding whether to sell items at an upcoming flea market or auction. Items with a realistic minimum bid of $5 or less, or very specialized items, are recommended for the flea market, potentially using a silent bid sale. Items of general interest, even if valued above $5, should be entered into the auction, and pre-registration is encouraged.

articles.title: Other thoughts
articles.summary: This document outlines the operational procedures for an auction, emphasizing a flexible approach to item limits and astronomical interest, likening it to a flea market. It details the SJAA's 10% sales commission (with a $1 minimum donation for registration) as their sole fundraising activity, also requesting commission on subsequent private sales.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document consists of classified advertisements related to astronomy equipment. It features multiple listings for various types of telescopes and accessories for sale, ranging from Schmidt-Cassegrain and refractor to Newtonian reflector models. There are also 'wanted' ads for specific equipment and a request for photographs of Comet Bradfield.

articles.title: MARCH STARRY NIGHTS BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: This article details a partial umbral eclipse of the Moon occurring on Thursday, March 3rd, starting at 05:46 PST. While the entire event lasts 5 hours, only the early penumbral phase will be visible from the western U.S. The partial phase will be visible from eastern Europe through Alaska, Hawaii, and the Pacific Ocean, where the southern half of the moon will appear slightly darker.

articles.title: TOTAL SOLAR ECLIPSE
articles.summary: A total solar eclipse is announced for March 18th, viewable in the U.S. only from Fairbanks, Alaska. The article provides specific universal times (UT) for the eclipse's start, maximum, and end in Fairbanks, noting the Sun's low altitude. It humorously converts the local time to "Sunset" and suggests the event could lead to "spectacular sunset photos."

articles.title: METEORS
articles.summary: The article notes that March lacks major meteor shower maximums but highlights two small, lesser-researched streams that could be active. It specifically mentions the Camelopardalids (March 14 - April 17) as an opportunity for amateur astronomers to collect and submit valuable observational data, emphasizing the need for more research on these streams.

articles.title: MINOR PLANETS
articles.summary: This article provides detailed observing information for three minor planets—14 Irene, 10 Hygiea, and 4 Vesta—for the month of March. It lists their diameters, magnitudes, and celestial coordinates (R.A. and DEC.) for specific dates, aiming to help observers locate these asteroids. A key tip for successful asteroid observation, involving plotting their movement against background stars, is also included.

articles.title: LUNAR FEATURES
articles.summary: This article outlines the visibility of specific lunar features, the Straight Wall and Plato, during March. It details the precise dates and times (Pacific Standard) when the Lunar Sunset and Sunrise Terminators will cross these features, serving as a guide for lunar observers.

articles.title: LUNAR APPULSE
articles.summary: The article announces a lunar appulse, and possibly an occultation, of the minor planet Vesta by the 8-day old moon on Saturday, March 26th. It provides coordinates for Vesta and notes that observing this magnitude 7.5 event will be challenging due to the moon's 60% illumination.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz reports the discovery of a new comet, Comet Liller (1988a), found on January 11 by Dr. William Liller using an 8-inch Schmidt Camera. Initially magnitude 10 in Sculptor, it is expected to be easily visible for several months, while three other comets are also well-placed for northern sky observation. The discovery by Dr. Liller, a professional astronomer working in his own time, is considered an amateur find.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: Comet Liller is expected to reach perihelion on March 31 at 0.848 AU and may brighten to magnitude 6 in April, making it a good target for Northern Hemisphere observers throughout August. The article also notes a trend in amateur comet discoveries, with many having similar perihelion distances.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides ephemeris data and observational notes for four comets: McNaught (1987b₁), Bradfield (1987s), Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p), and Liller (1988a), covering the period from late February to early April. It details their celestial positions (R.A., Dec), elongation, magnitude, and specific viewing advice, noting their fading visibility or optimal observing times for astronomers.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article delves into the unexpected media attention an amateur comet hunter receives after a discovery, contrasting the author's shyness with the prolonged interviews given by prolific comet hunter William Bradfield. The author prepares for common press questions, listing typical inquiries about the discovery process, the nature of comets, and the hobby's origins, alongside some unusual or 'dumb' questions.

articles.title: AN OVERVIEW OF OBSERVING SITES BY: DON MACHHOLZ AND RICH PAGE
articles.summary: This article provides an overview of observing sites along Mt. Hamilton Road (Hwy. 130) between Grant Ranch Park and Lick Observatory. It highlights "The Brickyard" as a recommended, level site offering good inversion layers despite moderate light pollution, and suggests several darker turnoffs east of Lick Observatory. The authors also advise contacting Lick Observatory security for observing on their property and mention access to exclusive sites through the Halls Valley Astronomy Group.

articles.title: BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article marks the end of the Jupiter "Spot-watching" season in March due to unfavorable viewing conditions, with observations becoming difficult by April. It describes the Great Red Spot (GRS) as a distinct brown-orange on Feb 5th, easily identifiable by a dent in the South Equatorial Belt. The author provides a table of GRS meridian transit times in PST for March and early April, offering last-ditch observation opportunities before a column hiatus until September.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz announces the annual Messier Marathon, recommending the weekend of March 19/20 due to a new moon on March 17. He invites participants to join him at Uvas Reservoir or other suitable sites like Grant Ranch Park and Fremont Peak. The article highlights mid-March to early April as the best period for observing up to 108 of the 110 Messier objects from their latitude, detailing object visibility variations through March.

articles.title: MEMBER INFORMATION
articles.summary: This document presents a table of member information, detailing names, associated positions or addresses, alternate contacts, and phone numbers. Following the main table, there are additional lists of 'CA %' codes and various city or region names, suggesting it functions as a contact or membership directory.

articles.title: SJAA 1987/N988 MEMBERSHIP ROSTER
articles.summary: This document is the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) membership roster for the 1987-1988 period. It lists members with their names, roster numbers, addresses (including city and state), phone numbers, and any amounts due. The roster appears to be an internal record of the organization's members.

articles.title: TELO
articles.summary: The document, titled "TELO," consists solely of an unformatted list of various surnames. No additional context or information regarding the purpose or significance of these names is provided within the content.

articles.title: PAUL E
articles.summary: This document appears to be a directory listing or contact list, featuring a collection of individuals' names alongside their respective street addresses, cities, states, and zip codes. The majority of the listed addresses are located in various cities within California, predominantly San Jose and Santa Clara, though other locations like Portland, Maui, and Hilo Park are also present.

articles.title: Anthology Club's 1990s Kickoff
articles.summary: The article titled "Anthology Club's 1990s Kickoff" appears to be a directory or listing of numerous organizations, clubs, and research centers, predominantly with an astronomical or horticultural focus. It provides names, associated cities, and postal codes, primarily for entities located in California. This compilation likely serves as a membership list, contact directory, or attendees list for a kickoff event.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, featuring guest speakers on diverse astronomical topics and "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share interests. These meetings, held on the 1st Saturday of each month, welcome enthusiasts of astrophotography, deep sky observation, telescope making, and general observing, starting at 8 PM.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes and accessories, with activities ranging from outdoor observing to indoor slideshows of astrophotography and event updates. These events also host board meetings and monthly introductory astronomy workshops.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays closest to the New Moon. These events are held several times a year at various locations, ranging from close to San Jose to as far as Yosemite National Park. Attendees are advised to check the EPHEMERIS for specific star party locations.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular deep-sky observing and astrophotography site for Bay Area amateur astronomers, known for hosting large gatherings during clear New Moon weekends. The article provides detailed directions to this 3000 ft. elevation location near San Juan Bautista. Additionally, it features administrative information for the San Jose Astronomical Association, including details about its monthly publication "EPHEMERIS" and a directory of its officers and board members.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership options such as 'Membership only,' 'Membership/S&T,' and 'Junior (Under 18),' along with their respective fees. It provides instructions on how to submit the form, including making checks payable to 'SJAA' and mailing it to the Treasurer or bringing it to an SJAA meeting. The form also includes contact information for the association and treasurer.
